title: Club Lloyds offers £125 to switch... but cuts interest paid
text:
Lloyds Bank has launched a £125 switching bonus for the first time to tempt customers to its Club Lloyds accounts.

Those who switch to either the Club Lloyds or Club Lloyds Platinum bank accounts using the Current Account Switch Service will be eligible for the sweetener.

But it comes at the same time as the interest paid on balances below £4,000 has been slashed from 1.5 per cent to 1 per cent.

Lloyds Bank has offered those who switch to its Club Lloyds and Club Lloyds Platinum Accounts £125

Lloyds said the switch bonus will be paid into customers' new accounts 'before the seven day switch process completes'. CASS pledges to switch over your current account including any direct debits in that time period.

The £125 offer was announced on the same day that changes to Club Lloyds accounts come into force, which will leave customers with less than £4,000 in the bank worse off.

Previously the bank paid a blanket 1.5 per cent interest rate on balances of between £1 and £5,000 to those with a Club Lloyds, or Club Lloyds Platinum account.

However, in a shakeup announced in July the bank will pay those with between £1 and £4,000 a 1 per cent rate, while those with between £4,000 and £5,000 will receive 2 per cent on that final £1,000 in the bracket.

The switching offer may be an attempt to try and replenish the current account customer losses Lloyds has suffered in recent times.

Lloyds Banking Group, comprising Lloyds, Halifax and Bank of Scotland, remains the UK's largest current account provider, but Lloyds Bank itself saw a net 22,000 current account customers switch away over the fourth quarter of 2018 and the first three months of this year, according to CASS figures.

For those wanting to open an account to take advantage of the £125 bonus, Club Lloyds requires £1,500 a month to be paid in, or else customers incur a £3 monthly fee.

In return, customers get access to Lloyds' 'everyday offers', which can give up to 15 per cent cashback on some debit card purchases, as well as some other benefits like cinema tickets.

Meanwhile, Club Lloyds Platinum is the bank's packaged account offering and costs £19 a month, plus an extra £3 for those who don't pay in £1,500 a month.

In return, customers get Axa travel insurance, AA breakdown cover, mobile phone insurance and some of the same benefits of Club Lloyds, but not the 15 per cent cashback offers.

After a slightly fallow summer, a number of banks now offer appetising switch offers if you are looking to change your current account provider.

HSBC offers £175 to those who switch to its Advance Bank Account, which requires you to pay in £1,750 a month or £10,500 in six months, and which also gives you access to a 5 per cent regular saver which lets you stash away between £25 and £250 a month for a year.

Meanwhile, NatWest and RBS both offer £150 to switchers to any of its current accounts, from their regular Select accounts to its monthly fee Reward accounts.

M&S Bank meanwhile offers £180 in gift cards if you switch and stay for 12 months. The first £100 requires you to maintain four active direct debits while the second £80 instalment requires you to pay in at least £1,250 a month and opt for online-only statements.

For a full list of the switching offers available and the interest-paying accounts, read This is Money's guide to the best current accounts.
